body.p:
APPENDIX 6
Royal Entry of Katherine of
Aragon, November 1501
This appendix provides examples, from manuscript records of the royal entry of Katherine
of Aragon in November 150I (see Appendix I), of the types of entry records not normally
transcribed for The Records but included as references either in explanatory notes to the
transcribed records or within diamond brackets below the relevant dated listings in Appendix 1.
Such records appear in the main body of the collection only when interwoven in the manuscripts
with records of theatrical activity or music. Largely such excluded records involve one or
more of riders to meet the entrant at his/her approach to the city, the rails behind which
companies stood along the entry route, the standings (or platforms, including rails) upon
which they stood, the breaking and subsequent repairing of the pavement where the standings
rails were placed, costs of food and drink, sand or gravel laid down on London Bridge and
in the streets (to cushion the horses hooves and prevent them from sliding), gifts, detail of
liveries worn, debts for riding costs, fines of those absenting themselves from riding (attendance
on these occasions being normally compulsory for company members), and other such non-
musical, non theatrical elements of these occasions. (For the cushioning of horses' hooves,
see Leland,Collectanea, vol 4, p 10.) Such elements were standard for major entries, and
many of them also for more routine entries not usually involving theatrical and for
which there are normally no records of music (although trumpets, at least, must almost
nvariably have been used). Also, although approvals of assessments to cover costs
at royal entries have been included within The Records, detailed collection arrangements
and arrears, such as those transcribed below from Repertory I, are normally merely cited in
endnotes or in Appendix 1 listings.
Katherine of Aragon and Prince Arthur (heir to the throne of England) had been married
to one another by proxy in May 1499, but Katherine's arrival in England had been delayed
until late 1501, when finally she arrived at Plymouth on 2 Qctober. A lengthy progress to
London then took place, with the royal entry through the city (from Lambeth) on 12
November and the wedding at St Paul's on 14 November. On 16 November the court
moved by water from the city to Westminster, for celebrations there with tournaments,
banquets, and the like. On 26 November a civic escort accompanied the court up the river
from Westminster to Mortlake (adiacent to Richmond). (See the main records transcribed
under 1499-1500, 1500-1, and 1501-2:, also Appendix I under 1501-2 (12, 14, 16,
and 26 November) and the ODNB.) The events preceding and following 12 November were

not part of the royal entry through the city, but company non-musical, non-theatrical
records of them have nevertheless been included below because, relating to the same period
pf celebration, they extend the range of examples of records not typically included within
The Records.
Several of the records require the provision here of additional information. For an explana-
tion of the last line of the items from Repertory I, see the related Mercers Company's record
below. The manuscript heading (not transcribed) for the payments from f 32v of the Bakers'
Company's accounts states that this account is for two years, 15 and 16 Henry VII (that is,
22 August 1499 to 2I August 1501)' since the company's accounting year generally runs
from one 23 November to the next, and the record concerns the 12 November royal entry,
the heading almost certainly indicates 23 November 1499-23 November 1501. In the first
Brewers' Company record, a list of sixty-four names, at 6d each, precedes the tota transcribed.
The third Brewers' record refers to jousts, records of tournaments or joustings which do not
mention either music or theatrical elements such as role-playing are by standard REED policy
excluded from The Records, and in any case these specific [ousts are at Westminster.
The Drapers' Company's record of barge hire to Westminster with the king is internally
dated 20 November; after the wedding on 14 October the court, as noted above, travelled
by water to Westminster on 16 November (see Appendix 1), so either the 20th is a payment
(not event) date or (much less likely) there was another occasion on the 20th requiring an
escort. A Drapers' record of payment concerning the water escort to Mortlake is included
in The Records because referring to music, and is also dated later than the date, according
to other sources, of the occasion itself.
The reference to Southampton in the Grocers; Company's payments transcribed is related
to Katherine of Aragons' arrival on 2 October at nearby Plymouth; she was supposd to have
landed at Southampton (see Kipling, Recyt, p 115). In the items from the Skinners' Company's
accounts, the reference in the second-to-last payment to all the times includes not only the
occasions mentioned in the payments transcribed but also the occasions of the hire of barges
to Westminster for the sheriff's presentation in September 1501 and for the mayor's oath-
taking in October 1501 (both occasions with transcribed records in the main body of this
collection). The transcribed record from f 60 of the Wiresellers' Company's accounts is followed
in the manuscript by a list of names and sums, but no total is provided, and not all of the
individuals listed may be providing money for this particular purpose; after the first eight
names come three without a sum (one of which is deleted), and of five further names, one
is paying for two or three years, one for two years past, one in part payment of a fine, and
one for this year.
The Goldsmiths' Company was no doubt heavily involved in the receiving of Katherine
of Aragon, since goldsmith John Shaa was mayor of London in November 1501. A manuscript
record (Goldsmith's Hall: MS 1520, p 385) of fines for two individuals absent when the
company 'ffetched the prynce & pryncesse frome Grenewiche' does not seem, however, to
be related to the entry, and the record has therefore not been included below.
No editorial headings have been supplied for the records other than those in the manu-
scripts themselves. The records have been ordered as in any one year of The Records.

For all document descriptions, except for the Wiresellers' Wardens' Account below, see
The Documents.
Wiresellers' Wardens' Accounts
The accounting year runs most often from one November to the November two years later,
for the Pinners, and apparently August/September to August/September in either two-year
or three-year spans, for the Wiresellers. Further detail on the contents of the manuscript is
provided in the BL Catalogue of Additions, vol 8: 1846-1847 (1864), 197-8.
London, British Library, vs Egerton I 142, 15th to 16th c., Latin, English, vellum,

as Wiresellers, 2 March 1497, and proposed ordinances
